author: .fjl
content: A question about EIP-7702: why do we have the chainID in each authorization?

author: .fjl
content: we only accept authorizations for the current chain anyway, and the chainID is contained in the transacction already

author: .fjl
content: I understand that it's an input into the signature, but we could technically get it from the transaction

author: .fjl
content: It would save a few bytes not to have this redundant information in each auth

author: .fjl
content: almost feel bad for bringing this up, since we're so close to the finish line with 7702

author: .fjl
content: but would be nice to investigate if it's possible to remove this field, especially since we are considering to expand it to uint256 right now

author: .fjl
content: ahh, I see that EIP-7702 also permits a `chain_id` of zero

author: .fjl
content: we could keep that case working by creating a boolean field that signals compatibility with all chains

author: .fjl
content: or combine with signature `v`

author: sky.cactus
content: I recommend against bit packing.  While it does save some bytes, the pain and suffering it causes for developers forever is quite high.

author: .fjl
content: yeah it's OK

author: .fjl
content: I wasn't entirely serious about putting it into `v`

author: sky.cactus
content: We saw this when chain ID was added to transactions with EIP-155, which resulted in many bugs and countless wasted hours.

author: .fjl
content: just want to see how small we can make it honestly

author: sky.cactus
content: RLP encoded number 0 is 1 byte I think?

author: .fjl
content: yes

author: sky.cactus
content: Or is this SSZ encoded?

author: .fjl
content: no it's not SSZ

author: .fjl
content: could've been, but we're not opening that back up right now

author: .fjl
content: published the above idea as a proposal here: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9152

author: .fjl
content: btw, in practice, this proposal will not save any bytes on mainnet

author: .fjl
content: the `chain_id` is one there, and under the new proposal the first element of the auth tuple is always one byte also

author: arnetheduck
content: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/issues/4064 - on block and transaction sizes - el devs are  in particular invited to provide feedback on approach (b) - (d) has its advantages but is pretty tricky to get right on the CL side

author: potuz
content: 256 bits on SSZ
